statement.p:
For each of the following geometric operations in the plane, find a 2\times 2 matrix that defines the matrix transformation performing the operation.
Rotates vectors by 180^\circ.
Reflects vectors across the vertical axis.
Reflects vectors across the line y=-x.
Rotates vectors counterclockwise by 60^\circ.
First rotates vectors counterclockwise by 60^\circ and then reflects in the line y=x.

solution.p:
We create the following matrices as \left[\begin{array}{rr} T(\evec_1) \amp T(\evec_2) \\ \end{array}\right].
\left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos(60^\circ) \amp -\sin(60^\circ) \\ \sin(60^\circ) \amp \cos(60^\circ) \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac 12 \amp -\frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \\ \frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \amp \frac12\\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac 12 \amp -\frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \\ \frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \amp \frac12\\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \amp \frac12\\ \frac 12 \amp -\frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \\ \end{array}\right] .

li.p: \left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac 12 \amp -\frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \\ \frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \amp \frac12\\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \amp \frac12\\ \frac 12 \amp -\frac{\sqrt{3}}2 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
This exercise investigates the composition of reflections in the plane.
Find the result of first reflecting across the line y=0 and then y=x. What familiar operation is the cumulative effect of this composition?
What happens if you compose the operations in the opposite order; that is, what happens if you first reflect across y=x and then y=0? What familiar operation results?
What familiar geometric operation results if you first reflect across the line y=x and then y=-x?
What familiar geometric operation results if you first rotate by 90^\circ and then reflect across the line y=x?
It is a general fact that the composition of two reflections results in a rotation through twice the angle from the first line of reflection to the second. We will investigate this more generally in

li.p: \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] . This is the same as a counterclockwise 90^\circ rotation.

\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] . This is the same as a clockwise 90^\circ rotation.

\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] . This is the same as a 180^\circ rotation.

\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] . This is the same as a reflection in the horizontal axis.
This is the same as a counterclockwise 90^\circ rotation.
This is the same as a clockwise 90^\circ rotation.
This is the same as a 180^\circ rotation.
This is the same as a reflection in the horizontal axis.

statement.p: Shown below in are the vectors \evec_1, \evec_2, and \evec_3 in \real^3.

li.p: Imagine that the thumb of your right hand points in the direction of \evec_1. A positive rotation about the x axis corresponds to a rotation in the direction in which your fingers point. Find the matrix definining the matrix transformation T that rotates vectors by 90^\circ around the x-axis.
In the same way, find the matrix that rotates vectors by 90^\circ around the y-axis.
Find the matrix that rotates vectors by 90^\circ around the z-axis.
What is the cumulative effect of rotating by 90^\circ about the x-axis, followed by a 90^\circ rotation about the y-axis, followed by a -90^\circ rotation about the x-axis.

solution.p:
We construct the matrices as \left[\begin{array}{rrr} T(\evec_1) \amp T(\evec_2) \amp T(\evec_3) \\ \end{array}\right].
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] , which is a -90^\circ rotation about the z-axis.

li.p: \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
If a matrix transformation performs a geometric operation, we would like to find a matrix transformation that undoes that operation.
Suppose that T:\real^2\to\real^2 is the matrix transformation that rotates vectors by 90^\circ. Find a matrix transformation S:\real^2\to\real^2 that undoes the rotation; that is, S takes T(\xvec) back into \xvec so that (S\circ T)(\xvec) = \xvec. Think geometrically about what the transformation S should be and then verify it algebraically.
We say that S is the inverse of T and we will write it as T^{-1}.
Verify algebraically that the reflection R:\real^2\to\real^2 across the line y=x is its own inverse; that is, R^{-1} = R.
The matrix transformation T:\real^2\to\real^2 defined by the matrix
A= \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1\amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1\\ \end{array}\right]
is called a shear. Find the inverse of T.
Describe the geometric effect of the matrix transformation defined by
A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac12 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3\\ \end{array}\right]
and then find its inverse.

li.p:
The transformation S should rotate vectors by -90^\circ. The matrix is therefore
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .

To check S\circ T, we compute
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .

The matrix defining the reflection is
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] . Multiplying this by itself gives the identity.

We should apply a shear in the opposite direction:
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .

We will undo the stretch in the horizontal and vertical directions with the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \frac13 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .

The square of the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]
is the identity.
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \frac13 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
We have seen that the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos\theta \amp -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp \cos\theta \\ \end{array}\right]
performs a rotation through an angle \theta about the origin. Suppose instead that we would like to rotate by 90^\circ about the point (1,2). Using homogeneous coordinates, we will develop a matrix that performs this operation.

Our strategy is to
begin with a vector whose tail is at the point (1,2),
translate the vector so that its tail is at the origin,
rotate by 90^\circ, and
translate the vector so that its tail is back at (1,2).
This is shown in .

figure.caption: A sequence of matrix transformations that, when read right to left and top to bottom, rotate a vector about the point (1,2).

statement.p:
Remember that, when working with homogeneous coordinates, we consider matrices of the form
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} a \amp b \amp c \\ d \amp e \amp f \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
The first operation is a translation by (-1,-2). Find the matrix that performs this translation.
The second operation is a 90^\circ rotation about the origin. Find the matrix that performs this rotation.
The third operation is a translation by (1,2). Find the matrix that performs this translation.
Use these matrices to find the matrix that performs a 90^\circ rotation about (1,2).
Use your matrix to determine where the point (-10, 5) ends up if rotated by 90^\circ about the (1,2).

li.p: \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
If we call this matrix C, we compute C\threevec{-10}{5}{1} = \threevec{-2}{-9}{1}. Therefore, the point (-10,5) is rotated to (-2,-9).
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
The point (-10,5) is rotated to (-2,-9).

statement.p: Consider the matrix transformation T:\real^2\to\real^2 that assigns to a vector \xvec the closest vector on horizontal axis as illustrated in . This transformation is called the projection onto the horizontal axis. You may imagine T(\xvec) as the shadow cast by \xvec from a flashlight far up on the positive y-axis.

li.p: Find the matrix that defines this matrix transformation T.
Find the matrix that defines projection on the vertical axis.
What is the result of composing the projection onto the horizontal axis with the projection onto the vertical axis?
Find the matrix that defines projection onto the line y=x.
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .

\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] . The result of composing the two projections sends every vector to \zerovec.
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac1{\sqrt{2}} \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
This exercise concerns the matrix transformations defined by matrices of the form
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} a \amp -b \\ b \amp a \\ \end{array}\right] . Let's begin by looking at two special types of these matrices.
First, consider the matrix where a = 2 and b=0 so that
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] . Describe the geometric effect of this matrix. More generally, suppose we have
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} r \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp r \\ \end{array}\right] , where r is a positive number. What is the geometric effect of A on vectors in the plane?
Suppose now that a = 0 and b = 1 so that
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] . What is the geometric effect of A on vectors in the plane? More generally, suppose we have
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos\theta \amp -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp \cos\theta \\ \end{array}\right] . What is the geometric effect of A on vectors in the plane?
In general, the composition of matrix transformation depends on the order in which we compose them. For these transformations, however, it is not the case. Check this by verifying that
\left[\begin{array}{rr} r \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp r \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos\theta \amp -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp \cos\theta \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos\theta \amp -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp \cos\theta \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} r \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp r \\ \end{array}\right] .
Let's now look at the general case where
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} a \amp -b \\ b \amp a \\ \end{array}\right] . We will draw the vector \twovec{a}{b} in the plane and express it using polar coordinates r and \theta as shown in .
A vector may be expressed in polar coordinates.
We then have
\twovec{a}{b} = \twovec{r\cos\theta}{r\sin\theta} . Show that the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr} a \amp -b \\ b \amp a \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} r \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp r \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos\theta \amp -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp \cos\theta \\ \end{array}\right] .
Using this description, describe the geometric effect on vectors in the plane of the matrix transformation defined by
A= \left[\begin{array}{rr} a \amp -b \\ b \amp a \\ \end{array}\right] .
Suppose we have a matrix transformation T defined by a matrix A and another transformation S defined by B where
A= \left[\begin{array}{rr} a \amp -b \\ b \amp a \\ \end{array}\right],~~~ B= \left[\begin{array}{rr} c \amp -d \\ d \amp c \\ \end{array}\right] . Describe the geometric effect of the composition S\circ T in terms of the a, b, c, and d.
The matrices of this form give a model for the complex numbers and will play an important role in .

li.p:
The matrix \left[\begin{array}{rr} r \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp r \\ \end{array}\right]
stretches vectors by r. It has the same effect as scalar multiplication by r.
This matrix rotates vectors by an angle \theta.

No matter which order we multiply the matrices, we find that their product is
\left[\begin{array}{rr} r \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp r \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos\theta \amp -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp \sin\theta \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} r\cos\theta \amp -r\sin\theta \\ r\sin\theta \amp r\sin\theta \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}
This follows from the previous part.
If we use polar coordinates to write \twovec{a}{b} = \twovec{r\cos\theta}{r\sin\theta}, multiplying a vector by A will stretch the vector by r and rotate it by \theta.
It stretches vectors by r.
This matrix rotates vectors by an angle \theta.
This follows from the previous part.
If we use polar coordinates to write \twovec{a}{b} = \twovec{r\cos\theta}{r\sin\theta}, multiplying a vector by A will stretch the vector by r and rotate it by \theta.

statement.p:
We saw earlier that the rotation in the plane through an angle \theta is given by the matrix:
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos\theta \amp -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta \amp \cos\theta \\ \end{array}\right] . We would like to find a similar expression for the matrix that represents the reflection across L_\theta, the line passing through the origin and making an angle of \theta with the positive x-axis, as shown in .

figure.caption: The reflection across the line L_\theta.

li.p: To do this, notice that this reflection can be obtained by composing three separate transformations as shown in . Beginning with the vector \xvec, we apply the transformation R to rotate by -\theta and obtain R(\xvec). Next, we apply S, a reflection in the horizontal axis, followed by T, a rotation by \theta. We see that T(S(R(\xvec))) is the same as the reflection of \xvec in the original line L_\theta.

figure.caption: Reflection in the line L_\theta as a composition of three transformations.

li.p:
Using this decomposition, show that the reflection in the line L_\theta is described by the matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos(2\theta) \amp \sin(2\theta) \\ \sin(2\theta) \amp -\cos(2\theta) \\ \end{array}\right] . You will need to remember the trigonometric identities:
\begin{aligned} \cos(2\theta) \amp {}={} \cos^2\theta - \sin^2\theta \\ \sin(2\theta) \amp {}={} 2\sin\theta\cos\theta \\ \end{aligned} .

Now that we have a matrix that describes the reflection in the line L_\theta, show that the composition of the reflection in the horizontal axis followed by the reflection in L_\theta is a counterclockwise rotation by an angle 2\theta. We saw some examples of this earlier in .

Compute that
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos(2\theta) \amp \sin(2\theta) \\ \sin(2\theta) \amp -\cos(2\theta) \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos(2\theta) \amp -\sin(2\theta) \\ \sin(2\theta) \amp \cos(2\theta) \end{array}\right]\text{.}

Compute that
\left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos(2\theta) \amp \sin(2\theta) \\ \sin(2\theta) \amp -\cos(2\theta) \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \cos(2\theta) \amp -\sin(2\theta) \\ \sin(2\theta) \amp \cos(2\theta) \end{array}\right]\text{.}
